Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Bohua Zhan is "Low-Dimensional Topology: Heegaard-Floer Homology." The host institution for the fellowship is the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Tomasz Mrowka.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the years 2014-2016, I finished my research done during the PhD years, on the combinatorial definition of bordered Heegaard-Floer homology. The work is finally published in 2016 as two papers in the journal Algebraic & Geometric Topology.


In late 2014, I began working in a different research area, called interactive theorem proving. The goal of this research area is to verify mathematical proofs using computers, by constructing a fully precise and detailed version of the proof, whose correctness can then be checked by an algorithm. This technique can be applied to verify proofs in pure mathematics, as well as proofs of correctness of computer programs and systems. I worked on the problem of proof automation. That is, how to use the computer to automatically construct the routine parts of a proof. In particular, I designed and implemented a proof automation system called auto2 in the interactive theorem prover Isabelle. I then applied the auto2 system to produce a formalization of mathematics starting from the axioms of set theory to the definition of the fundamental group in algebraic topology. This is significant in that it provides evidence that working in set theory can be as convenient as working in various type theories, as long as there is proper setup of proof automation. Finally, I applied the auto2 system to verify algorithms and data structures, giving relatively succinct verification of algorithms and data structures such as red-black trees, priority queue, and Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm.


These works, which are fully or partially supported by the NSF grant, are published at ITP (Interactive Theorem Proving) and TACAS (Tools and Algorithms for the Construction and Analysis of Systems), and Journal of Automated Reasoning (JAR). In 2018, I continued my work on verification of algorithms during a postdoc position at the Technical University of Munich. In particular, I focused on the verification of asymptotic time-complexity analysis of algorithms, with the work published at the International Joint Conference of Automated Reasoning (IJCAR).
